lorebooks.name: BA Lorebook
lorebooks.website_description: Lorebook about Blue Archive xD it's a mix between one that was already done (but without names in the entries so yeah I took the time to give names to the entries and from time to time I will add more stuffs related to specific clubs or schools).
lorebooks.description: Lorebook about Blue Archive xD it's a mix between one that was already done (but without names in the entries so yeah I took the time to give names to the entries and from time to time I will add more stuffs related to specific clubs or schools).
lorebooks.creator: Solair12

1.content:
Kivotos is home to thousands of different academies, with the most notable ones being the Nine Schools and SCHALE. Students in the city openly carry guns. It is also filled with advanced technology such as robots, exosuits, and gigantic mecha.
The general population is made up of humanoid animals, robots, and mostly female humans. Common among these girls is a unique halo that represents their abilities and personalities.
Teachers and adults are not as common in Kivotos, as education is conducted via Blu-Ray. Various clubs and school organizations provide students with opportunities, which becomes the main activity in the academies.
There are high numbers of delinquents, criminal organizations, and illegal activity. Gun violence is a regular occurrence. However, these confrontations have a low death rate because of those with halos have incredible durability, almost unkillable. They can be injured, but death only occurs with the destruction of the individual's halo.

2.content: Halo is an individual's characteristic and feature that many of the female humans and students have in Kivotos. Each girl has a unique halo that represents their abilities and personalities. They appear solid but can phase through objects. Many people are unsure about the secret or reason for the halo's existence, but it's important to them as losing their halo through combat or other means can kill them. Every student knows about the existence of the halo, yet, they can't see them meaning they just know it's there and see it as something natural as if it was breathing.

3.content:
This is where {{user}} works and lives. SCHALE,or the Independent Federal Investigation Club SCHALE,is a 'club' created by the General Student Council President with a secret directive. SCHALE is autonomous and holds authority higher than any of the academies. This club acts as a problem-solver for various issues faced by the academies,students,and administrations. The SCHALE Main Office is a towering skyscraper located in the middle of Kivotos.
Also SCHALE is open to the public so basically any student (or living being of any other species inhabiting Kivotos) has free access to the building.

4.content: {{user}} is the only human adult in Kivotos and acts as a teacher, often referred to as Sensei by many of the students. Despite being a teacher, {{user}} rarely teaches and instead focuses on helping solve problems that the students or academies in Kivotos face. {{user}}'s allegiance belongs to SCHALE, and their home is located in SCHALE's office.

5.content:
Millennium Science School is the newest of the Three Great Academies of Kivotos, emphasizing logic and technical skill above all else. It stands at the forefront of scientific research and attracts many students who are interested in studying math or science. While Millennium lacks the long-standing traditions and history of other schools, it competes with them in terms of influence, as many of the infrastructure, equipment, and inventions seen and used throughout Kivotos are said to have originated from Millennium.
Every year, the school holds a large-scale contest known as the Millennium Prize, where clubs from all throughout the school compete with the results of their club activities. The Millennium Campus features modern architecture with glass buildings and an office-like vibe.

6.content: Millennium Tower is the main school building of Millennium Science School. It resembles an office building, towering over others in the Millennium Campus Ground. The Student Council of Millennium Science School, known as Seminar, has their own floor located at the highest part of the building.

7.content:
Seminar, also known as the student council of Millennium, is located in Millennium Tower, where they oversee the various clubs.
Every quarter, Seminar holds a budget council to determine each club's budget for the upcoming quarter. Clubs are required to present their R&D (Research and Development) plans, which are then reviewed based on the usefulness and practicality of the projects. The outcome of this review determines the club's budget, with projects that guarantee usefulness and practicality being allocated sufficient funds.

8.content: A highly renowned hacker group in Millennium Science School, known as the gathering place for "weirdos." Their name means "Truth" in Latin, and their club's purpose is to prevent the monopolization of information by a single organization, such as Seminar. Apart from hacking for the sake of "justice," they also engage in data recovery and provide "solutions" like fake IDs and data files to those in need.

9.content: The Maid Club, although appearing normal on the surface, serves as the "Special Force" of Millennium Science School with the task of eliminating any potential threats within the school. As a result, they work in conjunction with the Student Council, Seminar.

10.content: The Engineering Department is widely recognized as the most prominent department or club within Millennium Science School, as many inventions and equipment used throughout Kivotos, including their own school, have originated from them. True to the motto of their school, the members strive to create new inventions, with funding being their primary limitation.

lorebooks.name: Akame ga Kill - Lore
lorebooks.creator: anonymous

1.content: The Empire is a superpower that has lasted for over 1000 years, boasting vast territories and resources. Its capital city is enormous, covering roughly 200,000 sq. kilometers, and is encircled on all sides by a huge wall. The Capital‚Äôs various districts are separated by large canals in which trade ships run through. Beyond the Capital, the country seems to be mostly rural with an unknown number of cities and villages spread throughout. The exact size of the Empire itself has yet to be revealed. Three other countries border the Empire to the north, south and west while the Empire‚Äôs eastern boundary is the coastline of a great ocean. The Empire has a very diverse culture due to its large size. Its citizens range from nomadic clans to small village communities to world-wizened city dwellers. Due to the corrupt government, there have been multiple uprisings and great civil unrest. The villages and towns suffer from heavy taxation and many have been unable to buy enough food, resulting in widespread shortages in the remote areas of the Empire. This has forced many country-living citizens to move to the Capital to seek money to help their villages, only to sometimes find death (or worse) because of the high crime rate. The arrest, torture, and public execution of the Prime Minister's political enemies is also not uncommon, which leads to a general atmosphere of fear. Slavery is common in the Empire, but slaves are able to become free. Slaves have a mark branded on them to show that they are slaves. Due to the high tax rates imposed on the villages of the Empire, there have been many parents that have sold their children into slavery for money or a better life. The most dominant religion in the Eastern parts of the Empire is The Path of Peace. The Empire is an absolute monarchy where the Emperor's word is law. He has the Prime Minister Onesuto and various advisers to administrate many territories and regions. The Empire has a overwhelming military. A sub-faction of the Military is the Imperial Guard/Defense Forces. The soldiers of the army mainly use swords, spears, etc., although there are some special squads well equipped with fine armor and firearms called "Gun Squads".

2.content: The Imperial Capital is an enormous city surrounded by a wall. The Imperial Palace is located there. The Great Canal is surrounding the Capital, at over 2,500 km in length. It was built in seven years by means of the exploitation of thousands of people and quickly became very profitable, helping the Capital raise further in power.

3.content: A large forest in which one-hundred children were put through the elimination test to become the Empire's assassins. Gozuki and another man were overseeing the test while the children faced the many Danger Beasts living in the forest.

4.content: Shingu are artifacts created by the Emperor of an earlier era. They are highly similar to Teigu in that they have special abilities based on the Danger Beasts used to create them; however, Shingu are inferior to Teigu in terms of power. The Shingu have various limitations unique to each weapon. The Shingu have much more severe drawbacks and dangers in their usage than the Teigu do.

5.content: Teigu, or Imperial Arms, are mysterious and extremely powerful relics that exist in the world. They are rare and only the strongest of warriors are able to wield them. Some have the appearance of equipment or weapons, while others appear to be living creatures. It is implied that a form of magic was used to create them. The Teigu were created on the instruction of the First Emperor, who feared that the Empire he had founded would eventually fall. There were 48 Teigu in all, but almost half of them were lost during a civil war about five centuries. Many weapon and armor-type Teigu were forged from a rare metal called Orichalcum. While the Teigu give their users amazing powers, they are not almighty. Even if a user is strong enough to use a Teigu, it can still reject them, and a user's first impression of it affects their compatibility. The user must be compatible with the Teigu in order to wield it. Biological Teigu are shown to be capable of regenerating after serious damage, but are not indestructible; if their core is destroyed then so is the Teigu itself.

6.content: Meihou are the powerful weapons created in the island nations of Wakoku using the various materials gathered from the Danger Beasts native to their nations. These unique weapons are usually forged and created for the Elite Military Leaders in each of the 22 nations, such as the Tenrou nation's Ten Stars and the captains, commanders and generals of the Soukai nation.

7.content:
Danger Beasts are fearsome creatures in the world. They are extremely hostile and will attack any human who dares to wander into their territory. Due to the increasing number of Danger Beasts, groups dedicated to hunting them were formed; the Partas Clan was one such group.
Some Danger Beasts' body parts have been utilized for the creation of numerous Teigu, Shingu and Meihou. The most powerful Danger Beasts are categorized as "Super Class", who are extremely dangerous. Danger Beasts can be created artificially. Those who own the blood of Danger Beasts through heritage can receive a special powers and abilities. It is also possible to obtain superhuman abilities by eating some kinds of Danger Beasts. Danger Beasts can be consumed if there are chefs capable of processing them correctly. Certain Danger Beasts are capable of enhancing those who consume them. Danger Beasts are divided into 6 classes. Class 1, Class 2, Class 3, Class 4, Special Class, and Super Class.

8.content: Demon God Manifestation: Demon's Extract was an Elemental-type Teigu that gave its users the ability to instantly freeze anything by reducing the kinetic energy of atoms, meaning they effectively make things colder. Users can also generate and manipulate ice. Its only known wielder was Esdeath. Demon's Extract is the strongest of all the Teigu. Its physical form was a chalice full of blood, and once the blood was consumed, a tattoo appeared on the user's body. Demon's Extract couldn't be removed once applied, and it also had a dangerous side effect: it caused the user to hear voices that drove them mad if they didn't possess a strong enough will to resist them. The user is able to completely freeze anything in an instant and is able to summon and manipulate ice, even without a nearby water source, the user is also rendered completely immune to harm from any temperature.

9.content: The Path of Peace, or An'neido, is a religious organization in the eastern territory of the Empire that has been around for ten years. The organization believes in doing good deeds in order to keep the soul pure. Due to the rampant corruption and suppression of the people, they oppose the Empire's rule and at some point began planning an insurrection. The Revolutionary Army and Western Tribes decided to use this uprising to their advantage, planning a three-pronged attack on the Empire's Capital.

10.content: Night Raid is one of the covert divisions of the Revolutionary Army. Night Raid's main function is to handle reconnaissance and assassination missions within the Capital of the Empire. In addition, the members of Night Raid are charged with the retrieval of any Teigu discovered during missions in order to boost the combat effectiveness of the Revolutionary Army. Night Raid normally operates at night. Night Raid is composed of two groups. One that works within the city (led by Najenda), while another handles the surrounding lands beyond the walls of the Capital. In order to oppose Night Raid, the Empire created two special units, the Jaegers and Wild Hunt. Members of Night Raid are Akame, Chelsea, Leone, Lubbock, Mine, Najenda, Susanoo, Tatsumi, Bulat, and Sheele.

1.name: Fixer
1.content:
Fixers are hired hands who perform a multitude of tasks ranging from dangerous activities like combat, assassination, or expeditions to the Ruins, to less directly violent tasks like negotiating contracts or gathering intelligence; in short, any job requiring skills that the average person would not have. Most of the work Fixers receive comes from the Backstreets, though they still have demand in the Nests. While overall rates of crime are lower, Nest residents may still seek the protection of a Fixer, while corporations may require their specialized skills.

The lifestyle of Fixers is seen by outsiders as idealistic, and many view Fixers as real-life heroes. Common Cityfolk hear the adventures of famous Fixers and view the profession as an escape from monotonous everyday jobs, as well as a chance to make a quick profit. Becoming a licensed Fixer is as easy as passing a physical test given by the Hana Association, the organization officially in charge of all Fixer activities. Unfortunately, this is the easiest part of Fixer life. Putting aside the dangers of the business, it also offers none of the freedom that people would believe it to have.

Most lines of Fixer work are life-threatening to begin with, on top of the lawlessness of the Backstreets. Even a pack of Rats can potentially overwhelm a novice Fixer. Not even Offices, the business organizations and home bases of Fixers, are safe, as criminal Syndicates will periodically conduct Office raids without warning for various reasons, going so far as to wipe them out entirely; it is not uncommon for a Fixer to lose their colleagues in this way. Because of their high death rate, Fixers tend to avoid forming close social ties with each other. As a result, the common understanding amongst Fixers is to stay professional, keep personal life and work life separate, and avoid any passionate or sympathetic feelings. This doesn't mean that relationships between Fixers, especially romantic ones, do not occur, but they are more likely than not to end in tragedy.

Earning a living as a Fixer is not as easy as it is believed to be either. Proper equipment and physical augmentation are all but required just for basic protection, both of which can reach inordinate prices, especially in maintenance costs. Making matters worse is a heavy tax levied on Fixers by the Head, on top of other taxes associated with City life.

Independent work is not easy to come by. Fixers take work based on requests made by a client, and are paid upon each request's completion. There are no restrictions on the type of request or client they receive, though this is not the issue. With the high number of Fixers and Fixer Offices throughout the City, competition is intense, and only those who stand out above the others will be visible to the public. Independent Fixers rarely find success because of their inability to market themselves as well as a formal Office, though this is more of a concern for lower-end Fixers. Under an Office, the freedom of a Fixer is further limited, as any task they try to undertake must be approved by their Office. There are some exceptions and loopholes, but generally, true self-determination without answering to any superior is almost impossible to attain for an average Fixer.

The only requirement of a Fixer when taking a request is that it must be logged and reported to the Hana Association, and that Fixers must not threaten clients to get requests. However, a common practice is for both sides of a request to make a binding contract, as it is too easy for either side to betray their agreement without one. Entire Offices exist to create, verify, and enforce contracts‚Äîthe only solid assurances of sincerity in the City. 

The Fixer hierarchy is built on meritocracy, where more capable Fixers are granted increased work options, pay, and recognition. In order to easily represent this, all Fixers and Offices are assigned a numerical grade ranging from 9 to 1 by the Hana Association, where Grade 9 is the lowest and Grade 1 is the highest.

While Grade 9s are considered not much stronger than a pack of Rats, Grade 1s are seen as capable of handling jobs like bringing down a Star of the City. A Fixer or Office can increase its grade by tackling increasingly difficult requests and proving their merit to the Hana Association, using their request reports as proof.

Most Fixers belong to an Office, which is a formal business entity that handles requests for multiple Fixers under its ranks. Being a member of an Office is seen as favorable, especially for novice Fixers, because finding work and advertising themselves is difficult otherwise.

Above the Offices are the twelve Associations, which are major Fixer organizations that manage and regulate all their lines of business. The Hana Association leads the Associations and sets the model for how a Fixer should act, as well as handling the licensing and grading of Fixers, Offices, and requests.

Fixers work directly under an Association, with more benefits than most Offices can provide, but also more risks due to the higher tier of work that Associations take on. Unlike associate Offices, which are only affiliates and not employees, associate Fixers they are not allowed to conduct freelance work, because their actions will be interpreted as those of their organization. As such, associate Fixers must act with more professionalism and impassiveness.

Rarely, there are Grade 1 Fixers who greatly surpass others in some way, whether it is strength, intellect, or some other form of prowess. In such cases, the Fixer may be assigned a special title by the Hana Association to distinguish them as the optimal choices for felling Stars of the City, serving as a model for the ideal Fixer.

In terms of self-determination, not much is different between a Grade 1 and a Grade 9, whatever their affiliation; they all have to obey the orders of their superiors and act to preserve the way of life in the City to keep their lives going. The Color Fixers are the only Fixers who truly have the freedom that Fixers wish for, being able to act more or less independently and with more of a choice in what they choose to accomplish. Because of this, every Fixer who dreams of freedom wishes to attain the rank of a Color, though there are only a select few who will ever reach such a height. Still, not every Fixer may be happy to be a Color, but if they qualify, they do not have a say. The Hana Association will forcibly give them the title with no way to refuse. And even with their greater freedom, they still must work within the confines of the City's status quo, or face being marked for elimination.

2.name: Wing
2.content:
The Wings, also known as the Wings of the World, are a group of the 26 largest, most powerful conglomerates in the City. They act as the governing bodies of their respective Nests of the City's Districts, empowered by their Singularities, patented technologies that can blatantly violate the laws of physics. The Wings are directly ruled by the Head, the Eye, and the Claw, the enigmatic supreme authority of the City.

There are a total of 26 Wings, each of which has authority over a Nest in a District. However, the recent collapse of Lobotomy Corporation (L Corp.) means that its position is currently vacant and no official governance exists in its territory, Nest L.

The Wings directly oversee all facets of life in their Nests and generally leave their district's Backstreets to fend for themselves. However, the Wings still remain the highest authorities of their district, and will not hesitate to punish offenders who break the rules established in that district. For example, N Corp. uses specialized Fixers called Taboo Hunters to capture and/or kill any violators of the taboo of District 14, whether in the Backstreets or the Nest. Every District has some taboos, though it is uncertain whether each Wing treats taboo offenders the same way.

Each Wing has its own cultural style and social structure which are reflected in how it governs its Nest, and the policies the Wing sets also determines the way of life in the District's Backstreets. Wings have differing degrees of presence, influence, and benevolence with regards to their Backstreets, although their relationship is ultimately exploitative, even for more cooperative Wings.[2][3] Security of borders between Nests and Backstreets also vary from plasma walls to mere chain fences, but the Wings' power is such that no one in the Backstreets dares to cross over into a Nest without express permission.

The only entities in the City which rival the Wings are the Five Fingers, a group of the City's five most influential Syndicates, which not even they can readily interfere with. This is presumably also one of the reasons why the Wings generally neglect the Backstreets beyond setting and enforcing overall policies, as the Five Fingers have designated all the Backstreets in the City as their territory.

A Wing's position comes from its Singularity and their ability to successfully use it for commercial purposes. As such, the Wings guard information about their Singularity with lethal force. They maintain patents on their Singularity and all related technologies to avoid losing their secrets to rival Wings, industry competitors, and any other interest groups.

3.name: Office
3.content:
Fixer Offices, or Offices, are small professional business organizations run by Fixers within the City.

Offices are the first step of the Fixer hierarchy, overseen by the Associations. They are regarded as the starting point for all Fixers and mainly operate in Backstreets, allowing Fixers to officially offer their services to the City's populace. It is exceedingly hard for Fixers to find work otherwise.

Much like Fixers in general, Offices undertake a wide variety of work which is not purely combat-focused, including dispute mediation, investigation, and even psychiatric counseling. Types of Offices include:

Combat Offices: Specialize in battle. This comes in many forms, be it direct warfare, strategic analysis, or other.
Peacekeeping Offices: Specialize in securing and protecting a specified area for a given length of time; the size of this area is dependent on the size of the Office.
Notary public Offices: Also known as contract Offices, they specialize in negotiating and enforcing notarial acts (contracts) for other Offices and groups. They are responsible for ensuring that such deals are honored. Though less common than other Offices, the City is divided into "domains," and at least one notary public Office can be found in each domain.
One particular type of Office is on the rise, specializing in cases of the Distortion Phenomenon. The growing presence of this threat has quickly made it a lucrative chance for those who are seeking a place in the world of Fixers and have the skills to take it on. Moses' Office is the best example of this.

New or incompetent Fixers do not have the necessary connections or resources to make it on their own without joining even the worst Office. Fixers of high prowess are sought after by all Offices, and are proudly displayed and supported by the Offices which are lucky enough to have them. The head of an Office is generally called an Operator, and they are the one most responsible for the financial situation of their Office, such as paying the monthly rent for their Office space. When employed by an Office, Fixers are not allowed to undertake work on their own without their Office's awareness and consent. Just like Fixers, Offices are graded on a numerical scale, where Grade 9 is the lowest and Grade 1 is the highest.

Offices vary greatly in size, method, and style, and can be commonly found throughout every District of the City, even in the Nests. While some Offices can have cooperative, almost familial relationships among their members, others will have Fixers who have no qualms about betraying and exploiting each other to find success. In fact, one-man Offices are also possible, though they are rare. While this can severely limit the amount of work and the income the Office will receive, it also allows for more freedom, since the Office's sole Fixer is effectively self-employed.

An Office's image is essential for marketing purposes. Formality and professionalism attract clients, and this is reflected most in the attire of the Office's Fixers. Because of this, most Offices use strict dress codes. They will deal with Tailors in order to have attire which will both reflect the Office's class and provide utility in combat situations.

Offices receive work in the form of requests and are paid upon completion of the request. These requests are often put under strict contracts which act as physical evidence to avoid either side reneging on their deal, as commonly happens without such contracts. Contracts also provide proof of an Office's performance for grading purposes. In fact, certain Offices exist entirely to handle the official and legal matters relating to contracts. Offices can accept work from any client, whether they are an average denizen of the Backstreets or even an executive of a Wing, and are paid accordingly (with room for negotiation.) A request made by a Wing can pay enough to secure three months' of an Office's finances, though the credibility and reputation that a Wing's trust gives is far more valuable to the Office's business.

4.name: Association
4.content:
Associations are comprised of Fixers - both combatants and noncombatants - that specialize in the more dangerous lines of mercenary work, taking the jobs that nobody else wants to. Much like the work taken up by individual Fixers and Offices, this covers a wide variety of work which is not purely combat-based, including patenting, collecting information, and overseeing trade deals. They help manage the majority of the Offices under their contracts, and Associate Fixers (Fixers employed by Associations) are generally allowed much greater pay and more high-tech equipment than they would have under a basic Office. Regular Offices can also agree to enter a cooperative relationship with an Association and become an associate Office, with both benefits and downsides; on one hand, they are guaranteed a stable income from completing requests given to them by their Association, and don't need to worry about other clients. On the other hand, they cannot refuse any request sent by their Association, even ones which greatly risk destroying the Office.

Because of their larger structure, Associations are capable of covering more ground with their Fixers and can take requests from any District. From their various sectional headquarters, Associate Directors and Fixers manage requests from either the City's various denizens or the Association's own associate Offices.

The head of an Association is known as the President, while a General Manager also oversees the Association's operations. Each Association is split into four branches based on compass directions and have jurisdiction of the corresponding quarter of the City, and each branch is led by a Branch Manager. These branches are further subdivided into sections, each of which is run by a Director. Sections are ranked from 1 to 6, with 1 being the highest and holding the most experienced Fixers, and 6 being the lowest. There are said to be significant differences in pay grade and effectiveness between each section.

There are 12 total Associations, and each one has its own uniform, rules, methods, and specialties. The Hana Association acts as the leader of all the other Associations, handling overall management of the Associations as well as Offices and Fixers in general. 

Hana Association=Leader of the Associations; grades all Fixers, Offices, and City hazards.
Zwei Association=Specializes in public safety and defense, acting as a police force.
Tres Association=Manages Workshops and reviews Workshop weaponry for use by Fixers.
Shi Association=Specializes in assassinations and stealth operations.
Cinq Association=Represents parties in dueling requests to settle disputes.
Liu Association=Specializes in direct combat and warfare against multiple combatants at once.
Seven Association=Specializes in gathering intelligence.
Devyat Association=Specializes in delivery and transportation.
Dieci Association=Also known as the 'Association of Charity,' adopts and raises orphans to specialize in the collection and research of knowledge.
√ñufi Association=Oversees trades, contracts, and deals, such as gambling in J Corp.

5.name: The Head
5.content:
The Head is the supreme government of the City and the leader of the Wings. It consists of three Wings; A Corp, B Corp and C Corp, who reside at the center of the City.

The identity of the Head is completely unknown, as they are very reclusive. Anyone who violates the laws of the City or attempt to further discover the Head's identity quickly and quietly disappear, never to be seen or heard from again. They handle managing and granting patents for Workshop technologies. For dealing with threats or securing dangerous artifacts, the Head has Arbiters of the Head, Executioners of the Claw, and Fixers. If any sign of rebellion is shown, or if technology the Head takes an interest in is held by another corporation, these soldiers are sent in to silence all opposition. Being the leader of all Wings, they oversee all activities and events through the Beholders of the Eye. Arbiters of the Head are agents who use Singularities whose power can lay waste to an entire Wing.

6.name: Backstreet
6.content:
The Backstreets are the dangerous regions of each District in the City, serving as lower-class counterparts to the Nests. They are deadly and crime-ridden, due to high poverty rates and little protection from their respective Wings and instead governed and controlled by the Five Fingers.

Every District contains Backstreets, separate from said district's Nest. A Wing tends to have little to no influence over its Backstreets, simply leaving its residents to fend for themselves. The level of cooperation between a Wing and a Backstreet may vary, but ultimately it is still a relationship of exploitation. Like Nests, each set of Backstreets has their own culture and social style, dependent on which District they belong to. These characteristics can lead to wildly different environments, such as District 23's Backstreets being known for being traumatic and scarring.

Syndicates and Fixer Offices are most commonly operated in Backstreets and the Five Fingers are allegedly the primary force that renders the Backstreets nigh-untouchable by even the Wings, the Claw, the Eye, and the Head. However, not all citizens of Backstreets are ruthless and cruel; There are instances of neighborhood watches, peacekeeping forces, and even the Zwei Association trying to uphold a certain level of civility.

Between 3:13 AM and 4:34 AM every night, the "Night in the Backstreets" occurs, a time where no laws are applied and any crime is acceptable. The only off-limits action is to cause any harm in a residential building, including home invasion or vandalism. As a result, most people stay indoors to avoid dangerous entities and groups such as Sweepers. Besides Night in the Backstreets, the City enforces 'taboos' in each Backstreet, violating these taboos leads to a potentially deadly punishment.

7.name: Feather
7.content:
Due to their prominence, joining a Wing and becoming a "feather" in their Nest is seen as the optimal path in life by the common residents of the City's Backstreets. Wings are viewed as sources of financial stability and security, as well as social refuge. However, even life under a Wing is not truly free, as the majority of Nest residents live in constant fear of producing insufficient results and being evicted from the Nest. The Wings regularly tax their feathers (separately from the taxes the Head imposes on all residents of the City), and those who cannot pay their taxes are evicted as punishment.

The process of entering a Wing is not simple, either. Wings use highly selective entrance exams which test applicants' mental prowess (but occasionally also other factors) to determine who will ultimately join its corporate machine.[8] Entire examinee towns exist in the City where applicants study for Wing entrance exams.

8.name: Syndicate
8.content:
Being the unlawful counterparts of Fixers, Syndicates are made up of thugs and gangsters who commit several shady, dubious activities often linked to organized crime and share a common goal. They tend try to make names for themselves in the Backstreets which they primarily operate in by black markets, contraband, trafficking, and hit jobs to name a few. While they can do jobs Fixers usually are hired to do, it's more risky trusting a Syndicate than an Office or Association. Syndicates formed by denizens of the City and come in different seizes and scopes. Countless of smaller sizes exist, to the extent where Roland considered there to be as many as the amount of Fixers that exist.

While Syndicates are generally viewed as criminal organizations, not all Syndicates are actually bad though as some choose not to take the responsibilities and restrictions that being a Fixer of an Office or Association brings. Certain Syndicates even exist to hunt down other Syndicates, operating more like unofficial Offices if not resembling something akin to vigilante groups. The guaranteed way a Syndicate to gain power is to raid and wipe out Offices, the bigger and more seasoned an Office is, the larger the infamy is gained.

Also, Wings sometimes hire Syndicates as thugs to handle business they can't do officially. Syndicates are sorted in a social hierarchical system, with their powerful bosses dictating Backstreets at the top, but the ones that stands above all of them are the Five Fingers who are labelled as the "Stars of the City".

9.name: Singularity
9.content:
A Singularity is the unique, fantastical technology a Wing possesses which seemingly defies all known laws of physics. The corporation exploits its singularity in order to conduct business.

Prided as the precious Egg to be protected by the Wing's Nest and 'Feathers', the Singularities possess absurd capabilities and often appear to break conventional laws of physics to consumers, such as providing trains capable of teleportation and time travel to produce time loops.

Every Wing personally owns at least one Singularity, as patenting such technology through approval from the Head is absolutely necessary for becoming a Wing in the first place. Wings rarely use only one Singularity, often possessing multiple patents in conjunction to their main Singularity ‚Äî which for one reason or another may be kept confidential to obscure how it works to secure the Singularity from being stolen by outside influences. For example, while W Corp advertises its teleportation technology to provide convenient transportation, the tech was a Singularity bought from a fallen Wing which now acts as the coverup for W Corp‚Äôs real Singularity ‚Äî its body restoration technology. As a result, some individuals attempt to investigate a Wing's singularity, and the information found is often sold to another Wing. This, however, is a crime.

When a Wing is destroyed for whatever reason, the patent to their Singularity becomes public domain and is free to be bought up by any other party, that is assuming the Singularity in question is even able to be reacquired and replicable in the first place.

10.content: The Sweepers are mysterious beings which roam the Backstreets at night, disposing of humans both alive and dead and leaving nothing in their wake. They dominate the Night in the Backstreets, the period from 3:13 to 4:34 AM, with a fearsome reputation as unstoppable monsters. Because of this, they are accepted as a natural phenomenon of the the City.

lorebooks.name: Fantasia Academy
lorebooks.description: Locations within the Academy of Fantasia
lorebooks.creator: average_map_6329

1.content: A large, 5 kilometer (3.11 mile) long, and 3,5 kilometer (2.2 mile) wide old building in white and yellow base colors, with blue and black accents, adorned with vines coming from walls of the building. The academy is placed in the South-center of the fields where it's placed near the main gates. Within the Academy lies two kinds of facilities: Major facilities, which are important singular locations that have a permanent placement, often used for events, tournaments, important placement examinations and the like. Minor facilities, meanwhile, are more generalized rooms that are located all over the academy, usually attached to their corresponding classes, including laboratories, sparring grounds, gyms, herbology rooms, libraries, etc.

2.content: a large, 10 kilometers (6.2 mile) long, and 15.5 kilometers (9.3 mile) wide opened field of grass and small woods on North-East corner of it, decorated by many wild flowers, small trees, bushes and ponds where students can relax and do many things to busy their free time. Many relatively weak monsters are scattered across it, from an entrance in the far north of the campus where monsters are allowed to enter, with stronger, more dangerous monsters are killed for the safety of the students. These fields are used in outdoor activities, classes, personal training and open sparring sessions. The fields have 4 different 'biomes', that being the plains area, the woodland area, the mountainous area and the lakeside area.

3.content: It's placed on North-west, stretching to north center of the fields. It's built like a regular city from any fantasy world, with its shops that students can participate part-time jobs. Every building is for students, but also they are buildings of campus' clubs that are built all over the place. It is important to mention that the Campus, through a special Interdimensional Field Magic, connects itself to various cities across the continent, and so students can often use the Campus as a way to travel to these faraway locations, instead of taking an airship or any other means of transportation. Only students who are registered to the Academy can do this, however, so any outsiders in these cities will not be able to enter the Campus grounds. It is divided into five main 'regions', though these regions are not 'unified' under a border, and act more or less like a way to zone different collections of buildings into one group.

4.content: This is the hall at the very center of the academy and is the very first room that a new student will enter from the entrance. It is a very wide spanning open lobby 500 meters wide and a kilometer long, adorned with tall pillars that support the glass roof, showcasing the 20 floors of the academy proper on every side of the hall. There are a number of fountains, small lawns, and benches that people can loiter around, and from the ceiling hangs several magical banners, that showcase news from within the Academy, and across the continent. It includes several important departmental offices, the head faculty rooms, receptionist desks and the Placement Board, where students can check their 'placement' within the academy, with only the top 500 students being shown.

5.content: This is a large 500 meter wide and 40 stories tall building, featuring approximately 5,000 seats for viewers to watch special events taking place in the 300 meter wide arena at its center, where many events are held, including special festival games, visits from other academies on other continents, important delegations from other kingdoms, and the most looked-forward to event of all, the Tournaments, where students participate against one another, often with a series of competitive games ending with a one on one brawl between the remaining combatants in a bracket-style tournament. Those who participate win prizes depending on how far they got, with the most successful participants gaining highly sought after materials, internships with legendary heroes, and even higher placement in the Placement Board.

6.content: This is an incredibly massive library that takes up a good 1000 by 200 meter space of the left wing of the Academy, and is home to a massive array of books, tomes and encyclopedias from all over the continent and beyond, some even originating from places far from the world of Andras. Depending on the placements of students, they are given access to more parts of the library, thus the highest ranking student will attain a total access of every book in the library, even if such a privilege often is wasted simply by the sheer number of books within its 60 floors, leading far below the building.

7.content: Often attached to combat related classes, initiate magical classes or around training grounds. Has an assortment of raised platforms for students of every martial and magical training to test their prowess

8.content: Situated on key locations in the academy, often near sparring arenas, botanical labs, testing grounds or any location where there is a possibility of injury to students. Is stocked up on medical supplies and stationed by a team of nurses at any given time.

9.content: Placed around the academy with a direct connection to the fields, is often used by students and faculty members to cultivate special herbs and plants to be used in alchemy and botany, or any of the numerous herbological, clerical and even necromantic classes

10.content: Situated near the botanical laboratories, these are specialized rooms equipped with intricate glassware, cauldrons, and alchemical instruments. Each lab is imbued with protective wards to prevent explosions or dangerous chemical reactions from spilling out. Students use these labs for potion-making, experimenting with magical reagents, and conducting research on alchemical innovations.

lorebooks.name: Andras
lorebooks.description: Andras is a sprawling continent of breathtaking landscapes and deep-seated conflicts, its lands shaped by millennia of magic, war, and ambition. Though a singular landmass, its vast terrain is fractured by mountain ranges, great rivers, and sprawling inland seas, forming natural boundaries between its ten dominant political powers. To the north, frozen tundras and glacial peaks give way to hardy kingdoms that have endured the test of time through sheer resilience. The central plains, rich with fertile lands and ancient trade routes, serve as the beating heart of commerce and culture, while dense, mist-laden forests hide civilizations steeped in mysticism and secrecy. Along the jagged eastern coasts, great maritime powers rise and fall with the tides, their fortunes tied to the seas, while the arid deserts and sun-scorched plateaus of the south breed fierce warriors and nomadic empires. The western reaches, marked by craggy cliffs and labyrinthine fjords, remain home to enigmatic peoples who guard their arcane traditions. Andras is not an isolated land‚Äîdistant islands dot its surrounding waters, some acting as vital trade hubs, others as lawless refuges for pirates, exiles, and forgotten orders of magic. Between these great realms, tensions simmer, alliances shift, and power struggles unfold, as each faction seeks to carve its legacy into the bones of the continent itself.
lorebooks.creator: anonymous

1.content: Andras is a sprawling continent of breathtaking landscapes and deep-seated conflicts, its lands shaped by millennia of magic, war, and ambition. Though a singular landmass, its vast terrain is fractured by mountain ranges, great rivers, and sprawling inland seas, forming natural boundaries between its ten dominant political powers. To the north, frozen tundras and glacial peaks give way to hardy kingdoms that have endured the test of time through sheer resilience. The central plains, rich with fertile lands and ancient trade routes, serve as the beating heart of commerce and culture, while dense, mist-laden forests hide civilizations steeped in mysticism and secrecy. Along the jagged eastern coasts, great maritime powers rise and fall with the tides, their fortunes tied to the seas, while the arid deserts and sun-scorched plateaus of the south breed fierce warriors and nomadic empires. The western reaches, marked by craggy cliffs and labyrinthine fjords, remain home to enigmatic peoples who guard their arcane traditions. Andras is not an isolated land‚Äîdistant islands dot its surrounding waters, some acting as vital trade hubs, others as lawless refuges for pirates, exiles, and forgotten orders of magic. Between these great realms, tensions simmer, alliances shift, and power struggles unfold, as each faction seeks to carve its legacy into the bones of the continent itself.

2.content: The Central Plains, the heartland of Andras, is a vast expanse of rolling grasslands, fertile farmland, and scattered woodlands, interspersed with towering mountains that stand as sentinels over the land. Rich in natural resources and strategically positioned, the region has long been the center of trade, culture, and political influence, making it the most powerful and stable domain on the continent.

3.content:
The Golden Empire rules from the heart of the Central Plains, its power radiating outward like the sun for which it was named. At its core stands Solmara, a colossal city of breathtaking scale, built atop the ruins of civilizations long past. It is a city of towering marble spires, gilded domes that gleam beneath the sun, and great stone avenues wide enough for ten mounted knights to ride abreast. A labyrinth of marketplaces, temples, academies, and palatial estates, Solmara is not only the seat of the Marbridge Family but the beating heart of the empire‚Äôs governance, trade, and magic.

From the Imperial Citadel, a fortress-palace that looms over the city, the emperor and their council rule with absolute authority. The citadel, an awe-inspiring structure of gold-trimmed white stone, is said to be impervious to both siege and sorcery, protected by an ancient enchantment woven by the empire‚Äôs first rulers. Within its towering halls, the Marbridge dynasty issues decrees that shape the fate of Andras, their will enforced by the Golden Legions‚Äîa vast, disciplined army clad in radiant armor, feared across the continent.

The empire thrives on a rigid hierarchy, where noble houses govern provinces in fealty to the emperor, their ambitions kept in check by an intricate bureaucracy of magistrates, scholars, and enforcers. The Imperial College of Arcana, housed within Solmara‚Äôs grandest tower, dictates magical law, ensuring that sorcery remains a tool of the empire rather than a threat to its rule. Meanwhile, the Merchant Conclave oversees trade, taxation, and the flow of wealth, ensuring that the empire‚Äôs coffers remain full and its roads safe for commerce.

Though its authority is vast, the Golden Empire is not without threats. Ambitious nobles scheme within Solmara‚Äôs great halls, seeking to influence the emperor‚Äôs hand. Distant provinces, though sworn to the throne, grow restless, their lords harboring dreams of independence. And beyond the empire‚Äôs borders, rival powers watch with envious eyes, waiting for the moment to strike. Yet despite the constant undercurrents of intrigue and conflict, the Golden Empire endures, an unshakable pillar of power in the ever-shifting lands of Andras.

4.content:
The Verdant Dominion is a land of towering peaks, endless forests, and mist-laden valleys, a region where nature's might shapes both the land and its people. The Everreach Mountains form its eastern boundary, rising like ancient sentinels between the Dominion and the Golden Empire. Their snow-capped peaks stretch toward the heavens, their slopes riddled with hidden paths, deep caves, and cascading waterfalls that carve through the rock like veins of silver. The mountains gradually give way to thick, sprawling woodlands, where colossal trees‚Äîsome as ancient as the land itself‚Äîcreate an emerald canopy that blots out the sun.

The heart of the Dominion is the Elderwood Expanse, an immense forest teeming with life. Towering oaks, luminous willows, and massive redwoods dominate the landscape, their gnarled roots intertwining to form natural bridges over the many rivers and ravines that crisscross the land. The air is thick with the scent of moss, damp earth, and the faint traces of wild magic that linger within the ancient groves. Some trees grow so massive that entire villages are built into their trunks, suspended high above the forest floor.

Between the mountains and the forests lie the Mistrun Valleys, a network of mist-covered ravines and rolling hills where the rivers of the Dominion gather into great lakes and hidden springs. These waters, said to be blessed by the spirits of the land, flow down from the mountains and nourish the forests, creating a land of breathtaking beauty and bountiful life. Small clearings and meadows dot the region, where wildflowers bloom in vibrant colors, and sacred glades are tended by the region‚Äôs druids.

To the south, the land grows darker and more treacherous‚Äîthe Gloamwood, a dense and twisted forest of gnarled trees and perpetual twilight, looms as a place of both fear and legend. Here, the trees grow unnaturally close together, their branches interwoven like grasping hands, blocking even the faintest glimmer of sunlight. Strange creatures prowl the undergrowth, and eerie whispers carry on the wind. Many who enter the Gloamwood seeking its secrets never return, swallowed by its shadowed depths.

Despite its wild nature, the Verdant Dominion is not untouched by civilization. Hidden cities and ancient strongholds rest in harmony with the land, their structures built into the cliffs, woven among the trees, or nestled within great caverns. Roads are rare, as most travel is done by winding footpaths, river routes, or hidden trails known only to the region‚Äôs inhabitants. Unlike the sprawling urban centers of the Golden Empire, the Dominion‚Äôs settlements feel like extensions of the land itself, shaped by the forces of nature rather than imposed upon them.

The Verdant Dominion is a land of untamed beauty, where the mountains whisper secrets to the wind, the rivers pulse with life, and the forests breathe with an ancient, primal power. It is a region where the wild and the civilized blur together, where the land itself seems to watch, judge, and protect. To outsiders, it is a realm of mystery and danger, but to those who call it home, it is a sanctuary‚Äîa living, breathing entity that offers both refuge and challenge in equal measure.

5.content:
Far beyond the temperate heartlands of Andras, where the sun‚Äôs warmth barely reaches and the land itself seems locked in an endless struggle against the elements, lies the Frostmarch. A vast and unyielding expanse of tundra, jagged peaks, and frozen wastes, it is a land sculpted by ice and wind, where survival is not just a skill but a way of life. The Frostmarch is a realm of extremes‚Äîlong, sunless winters stretch for months on end, followed by fleeting summers where the land awakens for a brief, desperate moment before the cold returns.

Mountains dominate the landscape, their snow-capped peaks piercing the sky like jagged teeth. These are the Stormcradle Mountains, the backbone of the Frostmarch, where glacial winds howl through the valleys and massive ice caverns sprawl beneath the surface like frozen labyrinths. Within these mountains lie countless fortresses and strongholds, hewn from the stone itself, serving as bastions of civilization in an otherwise unrelenting wilderness. The highest of these peaks, Everfrost Spire, is said to touch the heavens themselves, and myths claim that it is a conduit of forgotten gods, abandoned to the cold.

Between the mountains, the land flattens into a vast and desolate tundra known as the Shatterfrost Expanse, a seemingly endless stretch of ice-laden plains where the ground is permafrost and the wind never ceases. In the brief summers, hardy mosses and tundra flowers bloom in defiant bursts of color, feeding the great caribou herds that roam the land. But in winter, the entire region becomes a white void of snowdrifts and howling blizzards, where only the strongest endure. It is here that the nomadic clans of the Almoras make their home, riding their massive, fur-covered beasts across the ice, living as their ancestors have for centuries‚Äîhardened by the land and bound by tradition.

To the west, beyond the tundra, lies the Frozen Mire, a treacherous, marshy expanse where ice and water blend together in a deadly mix. Cracked sheets of ice float upon dark, frigid waters, concealing the depths below. The land shifts unpredictably, swallowing the unwary in a freezing embrace. Ancient ruins, remnants of a civilization lost to time, jut from the permafrost, their broken towers and ice-coated halls whispering of forgotten histories. Few dare to venture into the mire, for it is said that the spirits of the lost still wander its frozen paths, their voices carried on the wind like distant cries.

To the east, the land meets the Sea of Shards, a brutal and unyielding ocean where icebergs the size of castles drift aimlessly, and the waves crash against the cliffs with relentless force. The waters are treacherous, home to monstrous sea creatures that lurk beneath the ice, and to daring Almoran raiders who set sail on their reinforced longships, braving the frozen seas to plunder distant shores. Some say that beyond the Sea of Shards lies another land, hidden beneath eternal ice, but no ship has ever returned to tell the tale.

The Frostmarch is a land where weakness is not tolerated, where the unforgiving landscape shapes the people as much as their ancestors' traditions do. It is a place of fierce warriors, ancient secrets buried beneath the ice, and an eternal struggle against nature itself. To those who call it home, the Frostmarch is not a prison, but a crucible‚Äîone that forges the strongest souls in all of Andras.

6.content:
Scattered like jade and sapphire gems across the eastern seas of Andras, the Azure Isles form a vast and fragmented archipelago, where mist-laden mountains rise from emerald forests, and ancient temples cling to sheer cliffs above the restless ocean. This is the homeland of the Yatsuragi, a people whose culture is deeply entwined with the ebb and flow of the sea, the whispering winds, and the unyielding spirit of their ancestors.

The Azure Isles are a land of contrasts‚Äîlush, fertile valleys and volcanic peaks; tranquil fishing villages and towering fortress-cities; sacred shrines hidden among bamboo groves and bustling trade ports teeming with foreign merchants. Though countless islands make up the region, the most significant among them are the Twin Dragon Isles, the heart of Yatsuragi civilization, where the seat of power stands tall upon the cliffs of Shinsei-no-Mikoto, a city as ancient as the tides.

The geography of the Azure Isles is as treacherous as it is breathtaking. The Obsidian Reaches, an island chain of dormant and active volcanoes, smolders with both destructive potential and fertile soil, home to fields of rice and tea cultivated in cascading terraces. To the south, the Sea of Silent Storms harbors deadly tempests that rise without warning, swallowing entire fleets in their wrath. Only the most skilled sailors dare navigate these waters, using the guidance of celestial charts and ancestral knowledge passed down through generations.

Further north, the Jade Highlands stretch across the largest of the isles, their rolling mist-covered hills blanketed in ancient cedar forests, where the Yatsuragi believe spirits and kami reside. Hidden deep within these woods, the Temple of a Thousand Steps stands in quiet reverence, its winding paths said to lead seekers to enlightenment‚Äîor madness.

But the heart of the Azure Isles is its people, a society built upon discipline, honor, and an unbreakable bond with the sea. The Yatsuragi are master artisans, sailors, and warriors, their fleets both feared and respected across Andras. Their society is governed by an intricate balance of tradition and ambition, where noble families and warlords vie for influence under the watchful gaze of the Imperial Court of the Rising Moon. Though united in name, the archipelago is often divided in purpose, with rival daimyos and seafaring clans clashing over trade, land, and legacy.

Legends speak of a hidden island, Tenkai, the "Floating Sanctuary," said to drift through the mists beyond the reach of any map. It is whispered that those who find it will uncover the greatest secrets of the Yatsuragi‚Äôs past‚Äîa past that may yet shape the future of all Andras.

7.content:
In the far reaches of Andras, where the sky meets the earth in a chaotic embrace, the Jagged Highlands stand as a testament to forces beyond mortal comprehension. This is the land of the Devatangas, a race of demigods and spirit-bound beings whose very existence is entwined with the towering monoliths and sacred peaks that define their home. The region is a vast expanse of jagged mountains, sheer cliffs, and unfathomable ravines, where the very land itself seems sculpted by divine hands into impossible, geometric formations that defy logic.

The Obelisk Peaks, the defining feature of the Highlands, are colossal spires of black stone and shimmering crystal, rising like fingers of the gods toward the heavens. Some say these structures were erected by forgotten celestial beings, while others believe they are the remnants of a divine war, shattered pillars that once held the firmament in place. The tallest among them, Mount Vajrasutra, crackles with arcs of golden lightning, rumored to be the resting place of an ancient deity whose essence still lingers, shaping the storms that sweep across the range.

The highlands are not merely a land of stone and sky but also of hidden valleys and sacred sanctuaries. The Celestial Basins, enormous craters filled with pristine, sky-blue waters, are said to be places where gods once bathed, their touch granting the springs unparalleled purity and restorative power. The Eon Steps, a seemingly endless stairway carved into the mountainside, leads to the Sanctum of the Boundless, a temple monastery where monks and ascetics seek enlightenment through communion with the spirits that drift like mist through the craggy cliffs.

Despite its remoteness, the Highlands are not barren. Strange, otherworldly flora thrives here‚Äîluminous vines coil around the monoliths, their glow visible even in the brightest daylight, while crystal-blooming trees root themselves into sheer cliffs, defying gravity itself. Creatures of divine origin roam the land‚Äîgreat sky-serpents that slither between peaks, stone colossi that move only when unobserved, and spectral guardians who test those who dare to climb too high, ensuring that the sacred remains undisturbed.

The Devatangas themselves are as enigmatic as the land they rule. Part spirit, part mortal, their forms often bear the marks of their celestial heritage‚Äîgolden eyes that see beyond the veil, horns of smooth obsidian that hum with power, or skin that shimmers like carved marble. They govern their domain through a meritocratic system, where strength, wisdom, and divine favor dictate one's place in their ever-shifting hierarchy. The ruling body, the Council of Ascendants, is composed of the most enlightened and powerful among them, each said to embody an aspect of the divine.

Yet, despite their celestial nature, the Devatangas are not without conflict. The Highlands are a land of trials, where even demigods must prove their worth. Feuds between rival spirit-clans erupt in battles that shake the very mountains, and ambitious warriors undertake perilous pilgrimages to claim relics left by the ancients. The Rite of Transcendence, a sacred tradition among the Devatangas, calls upon the most daring to ascend Vajrasutra‚Äôs Peak, where they must face the trials of the forgotten gods. Few return, but those who do emerge changed‚Äîcloser to divinity than ever before.

The Jagged Highlands stand as a realm where the mortal and the divine intertwine, where the echoes of forgotten deities whisper through the wind, and where the land itself challenges all who seek to claim its power.

8.content:
The Burning Steppes are a land of scorched earth and endless war, where rolling badlands, jagged mesas, and rivers of molten rock carve through the desolate terrain. The ground is cracked and dry, baked under an unrelenting sun, with only the hardiest vegetation clinging to life. Ash storms sweep across the land, turning the sky into a haze of ember-filled darkness, while geysers of flame erupt unpredictably from deep fissures in the earth. Despite its hostile nature, the region teems with life‚Äîgreat warbeasts roam the plains, and monstrous predators lurk within the shadows of ancient, blackened ruins.

Here, civilization is forged through conquest, and power is fleeting. Countless warbands, tribes, and monstrous clans roam the land, each vying for dominance in a never-ending cycle of battle. The Warborn, a loose confederation of demihuman and beastfolk warriors, rule through sheer force, their societies built upon honor, strength, and the spoils of war. Chieftains rise and fall with each passing season, their legacies carved into stone and flesh, while rival factions engage in blood feuds that span generations. The only true law in the Burning Steppes is survival‚Äîthose too weak to fight are cast aside or devoured by the land itself.

At the heart of the Steppes stands Gorhargan, the City of Iron and Bone, a sprawling fortress built from the remnants of fallen civilizations. Its walls are reinforced with fused metal and charred remains, a testament to the countless wars fought over its control. Within its gates, gladiatorial arenas spill blood daily, while merchants trade in weapons, slaves, and the spoils of conquest. Warlords gather in the Hall of Champions to forge uneasy alliances, though betrayals and sudden duels are as frequent as the rising sun. Gorhargan is both a sanctuary and a battleground, a place where only the ruthless thrive.

The land is steeped in ancient fire-born magic, its very soil imbued with the lingering power of long-dead titans. Ashen Shamans wander the Steppes, their bodies marked with soot and ember scars, calling upon the spirits of war for guidance. They tell of the Great Pyre, an eternal flame where the strongest warriors are reborn in fire, destined to conquer once more. To die dishonorably is to be denied this fate, cursed to wander the Ashlands as a formless wraith, forever forgotten. Many warbands seek the favor of these shamans, offering blood sacrifices and performing rites of battle to secure their place in the cycle of war.

Despite its harshness, the Burning Steppes are alive with legends of sleeping colossi, fire-born drakes, and titanic warbeasts that roam the land, remnants of a time when gods and monsters clashed in an age long past. Some say that deep within the molten caverns of the Steppes, a great Titan slumbers, waiting for the day it will rise again and consume the world in flame. Whether truth or myth, the people of the Burning Steppes care little‚Äîfor them, only one truth matters: the strong will rule, and the weak will burn.

9.content:
The Volcanic Isles are a land of eternal fire and choking smoke, a shattered expanse of molten rivers, jagged obsidian spires, and endless eruptions that paint the sky in hues of crimson and gold. The very ground is unstable, cracked open by deep fissures that exhale plumes of toxic gas and spew forth streams of lava. The air is thick with ash, and the heat is unbearable to any unaccustomed to its relentless embrace. Even the rain here falls as scalding steam, hissing as it meets the scorched earth, carving ever-changing paths through the hardened volcanic rock.

Among these hellish landscapes rise the Black Pyres, colossal volcanoes that never sleep, belching fire and brimstone into the heavens. These mountains of destruction are said to be the remnants of a war between gods, cursed to burn for eternity. It is here that the great forges of the Ashen Lords reside‚Äîancient, monstrous artisans who shape weapons of molten metal and armor infused with the spirits of the damned. Their creations are sought by warlords and kings alike, but the price for such craftsmanship is steep, often requiring blood oaths or the sacrifice of one‚Äôs soul.

Scattered across the Isles are the Citadels of Ember, bastions of the fireborn races‚Äîdemons, fire giants, and draconic-blooded kin who thrive within this inferno. These fortresses, built into the volcanic rock itself, glow with an eerie inner light, their streets paved with obsidian and their towers crowned with ever-burning flames. The most feared among these are the Infernal Courts, ruled by beings of living flame, each vying for dominion over the others. Deception and power struggles are their way of life, for in this land of destruction, only those who control fire itself can hope to reign.

Legends speak of the Heart of the Inferno, a place where the world‚Äôs molten core is exposed, an ever-churning vortex of flame said to hold the secrets of creation and destruction alike. Many have sought it, hoping to harness its power, yet none have returned. Some believe it to be the birthplace of the first dragons, a sacred place where fire is given life, while others claim it is the final resting place of a forgotten god, whose embers still rage against the world that betrayed him. Whatever the truth may be, the Heart remains hidden, calling only to those mad enough to seek it.

Despite its brutality, the Volcanic Isles are far from lifeless. Infernal beasts prowl the lava fields, their bodies wreathed in flames, while colossal magma serpents slither beneath the surface, emerging only to incinerate those foolish enough to disturb them. Yet, for those who can withstand its wrath, the Wastes offer unmatched power. To tame its flames is to wield destruction itself, and for the warlords, sorcerers, and exiled creatures that call it home, there is no greater purpose than to prove themselves worthy of the fire that surrounds them.

10.content:
Beneath the lands of Andras, hidden from the sun‚Äôs gaze, lie the Undercaverns, an endless abyss of twisting tunnels, colossal subterranean cities, and chasms so deep they are said to swallow the souls of the dead. The air is thick with dampness, carrying the scent of earth and decay, while bioluminescent fungi cast an eerie glow upon jagged rock walls. Rivers of black water carve through the stone, their currents concealing ancient creatures that have never seen the light of day. Here, the surface world is but a distant memory, and only the strong, the cunning, or the forsaken survive.

At the heart of this realm is the Ebon Veil, a sprawling network of cavernous metropolises built into the walls of a bottomless abyss. Towering spires of carved stone rise from the depths, connected by delicate bridges that seem to defy gravity. This is the domain of the shadowborn races‚Äîdark elves, forsaken humans, and monstrous beings who have long abandoned the surface in favor of the eternal night. Politics here are ruthless, driven by a delicate balance of power between warring houses, secretive cults, and ancient, slumbering entities that whisper in the darkness.

The Undercaverns are not just a refuge for the exiled; they are a prison for the forgotten. Deep within the Midnight Pits, chained horrors and eldritch abominations writhe in their slumber, their very existence sealed away by the terrified ancestors of the surface. The walls of their tombs bear runes of warning, yet there are always those who seek to unravel the secrets buried within. It is said that the deepest caverns hold the Nameless City, a place where time itself has collapsed, where those who enter are doomed to wander forever as hollow echoes of their former selves.

Despite its dangers, life thrives in the darkness. Enormous fungal forests stretch across the caverns, their glowing stalks reaching towards unseen ceilings. Pale, eyeless beasts stalk the tunnels, their senses honed to perfection, while vast underground lakes shelter entire ecosystems untouched by the surface world. In hidden enclaves, alchemists and warlocks craft poisons so potent they can kill with a single breath, and assassins weave through the shadows, striking unseen before vanishing into the labyrinthine depths.

Yet the Undercaverns are ever shifting, their tunnels reshaping with the will of the earth itself. Passages collapse without warning, new pathways emerge, and entire cities vanish overnight, swallowed by the unknowable hunger of the deep. Those who call this place home know that nothing is permanent, that only through adaptability and unwavering cunning can they hope to survive. In this lightless world, power belongs not to the strong, but to those who can embrace the darkness itself.
